G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3 and \u00a7 20.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Boston Housing Court Department** pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3 and § 20, because the defendant is a landlord and the property is located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Housing Court.

G.L.\u202fc.\u202f186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord shall not interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises either directly or through neglect of obligations under law.

Lezberg v. Rogers, 27\u202fMass.\u202fAp.raw_text: Lezberg v. Rogers, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 115, 117 (1989)
Lezberg v. Rogers, 27\u202fMass.\u202fAp.proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential lease a covenant of quiet enjoyment, ensuring that the tenant’s possession shall not be materially disturbed. *See* Lezberg v. Rogers, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 115, 117 (1989).

Simon v. Solomon, 385\u202fMass.\u202f91.proposition: The covenant is violated when conditions substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises or render them unfit for human habitation. *See* Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371\u202fMass.\u202.proposition: A landlord’s inaction in the face of recurring leaks and moisture infiltration is actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14. *See* Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13\u202fMass.\u202fA.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13\u202fMass.\u202fA.proposition: A landlord’s inaction in the face of recurring leaks and moisture infiltration is actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14. *See* Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417\u202.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417\u202.proposition: Persistent leaks and unremedied defects that cause water penetration or mold are recognized forms of interference. *See* Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465\u202fMass.\u20.proposition: Persistent leaks and unremedied defects that cause water penetration or mold are recognized forms of interference. *See* Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363\u20.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363\u20.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the problem through repeated complaints and failed to take reasonable steps to abate the condition, as required by **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).

105\u202fC.M.R.\u202f410.000 et seq..proposition: The presence of chronic leaks and resulting mold constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, **105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.**, which defines such conditions as rendering a dwelling unfit for human habitation; violation of the code supports a finding of interference with quiet enjoyment. *See* Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424\u202fMass.\u202f.proposition: The presence of chronic leaks and resulting mold constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, **105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.**, which defines such conditions as rendering a dwelling unfit for human habitation; violation of the code supports a finding of interference with quiet enjoyment. *See* Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).

McKenna v. Begin, 5\u202fMass.\u202fApp..raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5\u202fMass.\u202fApp..proposition: Defendant’s ongoing failure to correct chronic water leaks and consequent mold growth constitutes a substantial interference, amounting to a breach of Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379\u2.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379\u2.proposition: Defendant’s ongoing failure to correct chronic water leaks and consequent mold growth constitutes a substantial interference, amounting to a breach of Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment.
